clinical_study.official_title: Transcranial Static Magnetic Field Stimulation (tSMS) in Essential Tremor

brief_summary.textblock: This is randomized double-blind study to study the hypothesis that transcranial static magnetic field stimulation of the primary motor cortex improves tremor in patients with essential tremor. Half of the patients will receive tSMS of the left hemisphere and the other half of the right hemisphere.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in postural tremor amplitude in the hand contralateral to hemispheren that received tSMS treatment compared to the hand contralateral to the hemisphere that received sham treatment, as measured by accelerometry.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in postural tremor amplitude 15 minutes after treatment, as measured by accelerometry.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 15 minutes after treatment compared to baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in rest tremor amplitude, as measured by accelerometry.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after treatment and 15 minutes after treatment compared baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in tremor frequency, as measured by accelerometry.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after treatment and 15 minutes after treatment compared baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in the Clinical Rating Scale for Tremor part B (drawing)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 5 minutes after treatment and 20 minutes after treatment compared to baseline

arm_group.description: 30 min of tSMS applied to the left motor cortex with sham on the right motor cortex
30 min of tSMS applied to the right motor cortex with sham on the left motor cortex

intervention.description: Transcranial static magnetic field stimulation (tSMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) technique that decreases cortical excitability (Oliviero et al., 2011; Oliviero et al., 2015; Dileone et al., 2018). Static magnetic fields suitable for tSMS are obtained with commercially available neodymium magnets. We will use a cylindrical neodymium magnet of 45 mm diameter and 30 mm of thickness, with a weight of 360 g (MAG45r; Neurek SL, Toledo, Spain), which will be applied with south polarity to the left or right motor cortex, using a tSMS helmet (MAGmv1.0; Neurek SL, Toledo, Spain).
intervention.other_name: MAGmv1.0 with MAG45r, Neurek S.L. (Toledo, Spain)

intervention.description: A non-magnetic metal cylinder, with the same size, weight and appearance of the magnet, will be used for sham stimulation (MAG45s; Neurek SL, Toledo, Spain) of motor cortex contralateral to the stimulated hemisphere.
intervention.other_name: MAGmv1.0 with MAG45s, Neurek S.L. (Toledo, Spain)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Essential tremor
Exclusion Criteria:
- MRI-incompatible metal objects in the body (e.g. cardiac pacemakers)
- other main neuropsychiatric co-morbidity
- pregnancy
